items.abstract:
<jats:title>The influence of iron compounds in the sulfuric acid catalyst on the SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> oxidation process</jats:title>
        <jats:p>The catalytic oxidation process of SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> to SO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> is the main stage of sulfuric (VI) acid production. The process run could be disordered by reason of the increased inactivation of sulfuric acid catalyst during SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> oxidation process. This paper includes the influence study of the iron quantity and forms, which is introduced into the catalyst active phase, on the reaction rate of the SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> oxidation process.</jats:p>
title: The influence of iron compounds in the sulfuric acid catalyst on the SO2 oxidation process

items.abstract:
<jats:title>The influence of the catalyst worktime on SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> emission quantity from the sulfuric acid system and the catalyst waste material</jats:title>
        <jats:p>The catalytic process of SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> to SO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> oxidation is the main step of sulfuric (VI) acid formation. The sustained catalyst operating due to its structural and textural modifications could disturb the process course. This paper includes the influence of the vanadic catalyst worktime on SO<jats:sub>2</jats:sub> emission and the expected amount of the obtained waste material of the inactivated catalyst.</jats:p>
title: The influence of the catalyst worktime on SO2 emission quantity from the sulfuric acid system and the catalyst waste material

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>The results of the research studies concerning binding of heavy metals and arsenic (HM+As), occurring in soils affected by emissions from Głogów Copper Smelter and Refinery, by silane nanomaterial have been described. The content of heavy metals and arsenic was determined by AAS and the effectiveness of heavy metals and arsenic binding by 3-Aminopropyltrimethoxysilane was examined. The total leaching level of impurities in those fractions was 73.26% Cu, 74.7% – Pb, 79.5% Zn, 65.81% – Cd and 55.55% As. The studies demonstrated that the total binding of heavy metals and arsenic with nanomaterial in all fractions was about as follows: 20.5% Cu, 9.5% Pb, 7.1% Zn, 25.3% Cd and 10.89% As. The results presented how the safety of food can be cultivated around industrial area, as the currently used soil stabilization technique of HM by soil pH does not guarantee their stable blocking in a sorptive complex.</jats:p>
title: Binding of Industrial Deposits of Heavy Metals and Arsenic in the Soil by 3-Aminopropyltrimethoxysilane

items.abstract:
<jats:title>The influence of the conditions and worktime on the waste vanadic catalyst amount</jats:title>
        <jats:p>This paper includes the research results of the vanadic catalyst study that was operated in PCC Rokita S.A. during a gaseous SO<jats:sub>3</jats:sub> formation. The physical properties have been studied: mechanical strength, bulk density and grindability during the five-year cycle of the catalyst worktime. The studies presented underline the prediction of the amount of the formed vanadic waste material.</jats:p>
title: The influence of the conditions and worktime on the waste vanadic catalyst amount

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>3-Mercaptopropyl-trimethoxysilane and [3-(2-aminoethylamino)propyl]trimethoxysilane were used to functionalize the surface of silica from Piotrowice in Poland to stabilize heavy metals (HMs) and arsenic in soil. The soil for the study was sampled from the impact zone of Głogów Copper Smelter and Refinery. The soil samples were exposed to five-step Tessier sequential extraction. The speciation studies were limited to five sequentially defined fractions in which metal content was determined. The addition of unmodified silica did not affect significantly the concentration of metals in individual fractions. Significant changes were noted upon introduction of functionalized silica in the soil. The hybrid formulations obtained significantly reduce the release of heavy metals and arsenic from soil sorption complex. The results indicate the potential use of functional formulations for reduction of metal migration in soil in the areas of exceeded concentration of heavy metals and arsenic in the soil, caused by industrial activity.</jats:p>
title: The influence of silica functionalized with silanes on migration of heavy metals in soil
